title: Updates for the API docs

content.raw: I know this isn't in the scope of this PR, but what do people think of swapping "simulation" to be "load_simulation" to be more consistent with using a verb for a function and a noun for a class?  It just seems more intuitive to me, but maybe I'm the only one.
content.html: I know this isn't in the scope of this PR, but what do people think of swapping "simulation" to be "load_simulation" to be more consistent with using a verb for a function and a noun for a class? It just seems more intuitive to me, but maybe I'm the only one.

content.raw:
One thing I've been burned on before is remembering that one should probably instantiate a YTArray from a dataset with:

new_array = ds.arr([0,1,2], 'code_length') 

or something like that.  Would it be worth including a note here to that effect?  or an "example" at the bottom of the docstrings?  Or alternatively, is there a way of using the YTArray constructor with a dataset keyword argument explicitly to do this, ie:

new_array = YTArray([0,1,2], ds['code_length']) 

?  It doesn't appear that this will work, but is there a way we could make it work?  Or even:

new_array = YTArray([0,1,2], input_units='code_length', dataset=ds) 

This needn't be something we do in this PR, but it seems like the appropriate place to discuss it.
content.html:
One thing I've been burned on before is remembering that one should probably instantiate a YTArray from a dataset with:

new_array = ds.arr([0,1,2], 'code_length')

or something like that. Would it be worth including a note here to that effect? or an "example" at the bottom of the docstrings? Or alternatively, is there a way of using the YTArray constructor with a dataset keyword argument explicitly to do this, ie:

new_array = YTArray([0,1,2], ds['code_length'])

? It doesn't appear that this will work, but is there a way we could make it work? Or even:

new_array = YTArray([0,1,2], input_units='code_length', dataset=ds)

This needn't be something we do in this PR, but it seems like the appropriate place to discuss it.

content.raw: Aside from my questions, this looks great, @ngoldbaum .
content.html: Aside from my questions, this looks great, Nathan Goldbaum .

content.raw: Then I would say load should be load_dataset.
content.html: Then I would say load should be load_dataset.

content.raw: You need to pass `ds.unit_registry` into the `YTArray` constructor.  See the updates to the docstrings.
content.html: You need to pass ds.unit_registry into the YTArray constructor. See the updates to the docstrings.

content.raw: Well, it probably should be.  But I am -1 on changing load, -0 on changing simulation.
content.html: Well, it probably should be. But I am -1 on changing load, -0 on changing simulation.

chummels one can do a variant of your final thing by doing:

ds.arr([0,1,2], 'code_length')

which will get the right unit registry, etc.

content.raw: This changed because `input` is a builtin!

Simulation was initially meant to be short-hand for a time-series from a single simulation.  Now that I remind myself of this, I would prefer to keep it as is.  As ~100% of the user-base right there, that probably covers it.
content.html: Simulation was initially meant to be short-hand for a time-series from a single simulation. Now that I remind myself of this, I would prefer to keep it as is. As ~100% of the user-base right there, that probably covers it.

content.raw: I'm done updating this for now.  I think this is ready to go in once someone else looks this over.
content.html: I'm done updating this for now. I think this is ready to go in once someone else looks this over.

content.raw: Thanks for updating the docstrings.  Clearer!

description: This updates the API docs to include a number of classes that were missing, removes a few deprecated classes (`BinnedProfile[1-3]D`) and adds docstrings in several places.
